11-12.title: November 12
11-12.saints:
THE HOLY MARTYR ZENOBIUS AND HIS SISTER ZENOBIA

They were from Aegea in Cilicia. Zenobius was a priest and a physician. He brought the pagans to the Christian Faith, both by teaching them with words and by healing them from sickness through the invocation of the name of the Lord Jesus. Many of them were baptized. During the persecution of Diocletian, Zenobius was captured and brought to trial. The judge, Lysias, first tried to turn him from the Christian Faith by flattery, and when that did not help, he resorted to torture. But when even the torture did not help, he ordered that Zenobius be thrown into a fiery furnace. At that moment his sister, Zenobia, cried out: "Increase, O Lord, the strength of Thy servant!" The judge ordered that she be thrown into the fire as well. When they emerged unharmed from the furnace, the furious judge ordered that they both be beheaded. Thus, these holy martyrs took up their habitation in the Kingdom of Christ.

THE HOLY MARTYR ANASTASIUS THE FULLER

Anastasius was from Aquileia near Rome and, by trade, a fuller. He was not a Christian, and did not believe in Christ. However, a miraculous occurrence compelled him to believe. A Christian woman had lost a piglet and could not find it anywhere. The fuller told her that her God could not help her because He had no power even to find a piglet. But the woman said: "Let us look to see whose God is more powerful. Let us both fast for three days, you to your idols and I to my God." Anastasius agreed to that. On the third day, the woman found the piglet, and Anastasius received faith in Christ. Shortly after that, the persecution of Christians began. Anastasius took up the Cross of Christ and went to martyrdom. He was tortured in various ways and, finally, was thrown into the sea with a stone around his neck. Christians found his dead body, illuminated by a heavenly light, and buried him. He suffered honorably for the Lord in the year 304 A.D., during the reign of Diocletian.
11-12.hymns:
THE HOLY MARTYRS ZENOBIUS AND ZENOBIA

Zenobius and Zenobia,
Brother and sister, both martyrs,
Both holy before God,
Both unwavering in their confession:
"We are Christians! We are Christians!"
And the wild beasts did not devour them,
Nor did the fire consume them,
Nor did the sword frighten them.
They overcame all by the power of Christ,
And now, as victors, they stand before Him,
Before the throne of the All-glorious One,
Where the angels sing eternally,
And where the righteous rejoice forever.
11-12.reflection: What is the sign of holiness? The sign of holiness is moral purity, coupled with spiritual powerâ€”power over demons, power over the passions, power over nature, and power over every visible and invisible evil power. This power is given to man by the Lord Jesus, the All-powerful Victor. And such power is not given for ostentation and vainglory, but for the sake of helping men, and for the glory of God. St. Zenobius had such power and used it for the benefit of mankind and to the glory of God. He healed all manner of illnesses; he cast out demons; and he brought men to the knowledge of the One, Living God.
11-12.homily:
HOMILY ON THE RESURRECTION

"For since by man came death, by man came also the resurrection of the dead" (1 Corinthians 15:21).

One man brought death, and one Man brought resurrection. One man sinned, and one Man atoned for sin. The first man is Adam, and the second Man is Christ. Christ is the New Adam. The Old Adam is the cause of death, and the New Adam is the cause of resurrection and life eternal.

Christ's resurrection is the beginning of the general resurrection. His resurrection proves that our resurrection is possible. His resurrection shows us the way to resurrection. If He had not been resurrected, how could we hope for resurrection? If He, the Holy and Sinless One, had not been resurrected, how could we sinners hope for resurrection?

O resurrected Lord, help us to follow Thy path to resurrection and life eternal.

To Thee be glory and praise forever. Amen.

11-13.title: November 13
11-13.saints:
THE HOLY APOSTLE STACHYS

Stachys was one of the Seventy Apostles, and a co-worker of the Apostle Andrew. St. Andrew consecrated him as Bishop of Byzantium. Stachys ruled the Church of God with zeal and honor for sixteen years, and went to his rest in the Lord.

THE VENERABLE JOHN CHRYSOSTOM, PATRIARCH OF CONSTANTINOPLE

John was born in Antioch in the year 347 A.D. His father, Secundus, was a high-ranking military officer. The pious Anthusa was his mother, and the learned Libanius was his teacher. By the age of twenty-three, John had mastered philosophy and rhetoric. When his mother died, he became a monk. He spent four years in the company of an elder and another two years alone in a cave. Forced to leave his cave because of illness, John, at the age of thirty-one, was ordained as a deacon. At the age of forty, he was ordained a priest by Flavian of Antioch, and for twelve years he served as a model priest.

In 397 A.D., Emperor Arcadius called John to Constantinople to be the patriarch. He governed the Church of Constantinople for six years with enormous zeal and wisdom. He was a great enemy of the Arians and pagans, of civil and ecclesiastical corruption. As a patriarch, John lived in the greatest poverty and gave everything to the poor. A strong conscience prompted him to publicly reprimand the dissolute Empress Eudoxia, and that was the cause of his downfall.
11-13.hymns:
SAINT JOHN CHRYSOSTOM

O John, Golden Mouth, God's true trumpet,
You spoke the truth--and that was all--
The truth, and not what people wanted to hear,
Not smooth and honeyed words, nor words that flatter.
You cried out against sin like an eagle,
And exposed sin with a voice of thunder.
From the heights, your gaze penetrated the darkness,
There where men weave evil in the darkness.
And to the sick, you were a healing balm,
Your words more powerful than any medicine.
Your words were sharper than a two-edged sword:
They tore the chains of sin and unbelief,
But also brought comfort and courage to the righteous.
Glory to your holy name, O John!
Pray for us to Christ, that He receive our souls.
11-13.reflection: Man is like a watchtower between heaven and earth. One part of man's nature is directed upward toward heaven, and the other part is directed downward toward the earth. His spirit is directed upward toward heaven, and his flesh is directed downward toward the earth. Whichever is stronger rules over the other. If the flesh is stronger, it turns man's entire gaze toward the earth; if the spirit is stronger, it turns man's entire gaze toward heaven. Great are those who have succeeded in turning the gaze of their entire being toward heaven. Such were all the saints of God. Such was St. John Chrysostom. In this is reflected his spiritual greatness.
11-13.homily:
HOMILY ON THE RESURRECTION OF THE DEAD

"For as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive" (1 Corinthians 15:22).

In Adam, life is sown in shame; in Christ, life is raised in glory. Sin is from Adam and justice is from Christ. Weakness and death come from Adam, and strength and life come from Christ. Thus, in Adam we all die. And thus, in Christ we shall all be brought to life. That one is the earthly man; this one is the heavenly man. That is the bodily man and this is the spiritual man.

Christ did not resurrect for His sake but for our sake, just as He did not die for His sake but for our sake. If His resurrection does not signify our resurrection, then His Resurrection is bitterness and not sweetness. Where, then, would the love of God be? Where, then, would the meaning of our miserable earthly experience be?

O resurrected Lord, sober the minds of all the sons of men, that they would flee from darkness and destruction and reach out toward light and life eternal, which is in Thee.

To Thee be glory and praise forever. Amen.

11-14.title: November 14
11-14.saints:
THE HOLY APOSTLE PHILIP

Philip was born in Bethsaida, the same town as Peter and Andrew. Following the Lord Jesus, Philip was a faithful and zealous apostle. After the descent of the Holy Spirit, Philip preached the Gospel throughout Asia Minor. He endured much for the sake of Christ: imprisonment, beatings, and ridicule. Finally, in the city of Hierapolis in Phrygia, he was crucified upside down on a tree. Even on the tree, he did not cease to proclaim Christ, and when the people demanded that he be taken down, he refused and said that he would not come down alive, but would go to his long-desired rest. And so he gave up his spirit to God.

THE HOLY MARTYR JUSTUS

Justus was a Roman soldier who was martyred for Christ during the reign of Trajan.
11-14.hymns:
THE HOLY APOSTLE PHILIP

Philip the Apostle, servant of Christ,
Preached the Gospel to many nations,
And baptized many in the name of the Trinity.
He healed the sick and cast out demons,
And brought many to the knowledge of God.
For this, he was crucified upside down,
But even on the cross, he did not cease to preach.
He died as he had lived: proclaiming Christ.
Glory to God for His holy apostle!
11-14.reflection: The apostles were simple men, without worldly education or power. Yet they turned the world upside down. How? By the power of the Holy Spirit. The power of the Holy Spirit is greater than all the power of the world. The apostles had nothing but the Holy Spirit, and that was enough. We have many things, but if we do not have the Holy Spirit, we have nothing.
11-14.homily:
HOMILY ON PEACE

"Peace I leave with you, my peace I give unto you" (John 14:27).

The peace of Christ is not the peace of the world. The world gives a false peace, a peace based on compromise with sin. But Christ gives true peace, a peace based on victory over sin. The world's peace is temporary and fragile. Christ's peace is eternal and unshakable.

O Lord Jesus, give us Thy peace, that we may have rest in our souls.

To Thee be glory and praise forever. Amen.
